channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Obama Said to Back Airdrops for Iraqis
item.description: President Obama approved airdrops of food and medicine to address a crisis among as many as 40,000 religious minorities, according to administration officials. While Kurds and Iraqis said the U.S. had bombed two towns seized by militants, the Pentagon denied American involvement.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER, MARK LANDLER and ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iraqi Yazidi people who fled their homes in Sinjar took shelter at Bajid Kandal refugee camp in Dohuk Province on Thursday.

item.title: Islamist Fighters Rout Kurds in Northern Iraq and Seize Dam
item.description: The dam supplies electricity for a large region of northern Iraq, including the city of Mosul. Its capture has alarmed residents, already fleeing their homes from advancing Sunni extremists.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Displaced people from the minority Yazidi sect, fleeing the violence in the Iraqi town of Sinjar west of Mosul, took refuge on Thursday in Dohuk province.

item.title: Key Cleric in Egypt Rejects Executions
item.description: In a rare rebuke, Egypt’s highest Muslim religious authority refused to approve court-ordered death sentences on leaders of the Muslim Brotherhood, court officials said.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MERNA THOMAS
item.media:description: Mohamed Badie, leader of the Muslim Brotherhood, at trial.

item.title: Ukrainian Army’s Artillery Hits Hospital, Killing Dental Patient
item.description: The barrage was apparently aimed at a rebel headquarters in Donetsk when it hit a hospital nearby.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nurse ran toward the basement of a destroyed dental clinic in Donetsk as shelling from Ukrainian troops outside the city restarted nearby.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: In the Grip of Ebola
item.description: Liberia’s leaders first quarantined reporting, not the disease.
item.dc:creator: By WADE C. L. WILLIAMS

item.title: Kerry Visits Afghanistan to Urge Deal on the Election
item.description: The Obama administration is pressing the Afghans to inaugurate a president before NATO nations hold a summit meeting in Wales in early September.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:credit: State Department, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry walked with Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr., the commander of American and allied forces in Afghanistan, on Thursday after arriving in Kabul.

item.title: At War Blog: Dean Baquet, Times Executive Editor, on the Word ‘Torture’
item.description: Times editors and reporters revisit the use of the word “torture” in connection to C.I.A. interrogations.
item.dc:creator: By DEAN BAQUET

item.title: Russia Responds to Western Sanctions With Import Bans of Its Own
item.description: Moscow announced a ban on all beef, pork, fruit, vegetables and dairy products from the European Union, the United States, Canada, Australia and Norway.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR and ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Dmitry Astakhov/RIA Novosti, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Dmitri A. Medvedev, the Russian prime minister, announced that Russia would ban all beef, pork, fruit, vegetables and dairy products from the European Union, the United States, Canada, Australia and Norway for one year.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Animal Activists Notch a Win Against Dog Traders
item.description: A group of animal lovers from across China rescued about 2,400 dogs that might have otherwise ended up on the dinner table.
item.dc:creator: By BECKY DAVIS
item.media:description: Animal welfare advocates climbed on top of dog cages on a truck, bringing food and water to the animals and disposing of those that had died.

item.title: Open Source: Israel’s Supporters Try to Come to Terms With the Killing of Children in Gaza
item.description: Outrage over the killing of hundreds of children has been expressed by partisans on both sides of the conflict.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Militants in Iraq Hit by Strikes, Kurds Say
item.description: While Kurdish officials said the U.S. had bombed two towns seized by members of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the Pentagon denied that U.S. forces were involved.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Iraqis who fled their homes in Sinjar were transported to Dohuk Province on Thursday.

item.title: China Moves to Rein in Messaging for Mobile
item.description: New rules, widely believed to be aimed at WeChat, are intended to curb the sharing of unauthorized political news and information.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: China imposed new restrictions on the country’s most popular mobile instant messaging services on Thursday, WeChat, including rules meant to curb the sharing of political news.

item.title: Letter From Europe: War Reshapes the World Once Again
item.description: Compared with World War I, today's flash points may seem like extended brush fires. But there are those who think these conflicts have made the world more dangerous than ever.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: An ominous black cloud from a fuel fire floats over a World War Two monument in Donetsk, Ukraine. A conflict there and in several other places around the world are reminders of the cost of the last century's wars.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Only 9 Chinese Cities Pass Clean Air Test
item.description: Nine out of 161 monitored cities met China’s new air quality standards in the first half of this year, the Ministry of Environmental Protection said.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: A street scene in Beijing, where 20 million residents regularly experience unhealthy levels of pollution.

item.title: Snowden Said to Be Allowed 3 More Years in Russia
item.description: Edward J. Snowden, the American former intelligence technician who leaked thousands of classified files, was originally granted one year of residency.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Sunni Extremists Appear to Capture Iraq’s Largest Dam
item.description: Advances by ISIS in the country’s north created an onslaught of refugees and set off fearful rumors in Erbil, the Kurdish regional capital.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Civilians fleeing the fighting in northern Iraq on Wednesday arrived at a Kurdish pesh merga checkpoint between Erbil and Mosul.

item.title: Jason Rezaian of Washington Post and Wife Still Held
item.description: The arrest of Jason Rezaian of The Washington Post has alarmed the foreign press corps and highlights the split between Iran’s president and the state institutions that hold the real power.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Zoeann Murphy/The Washington Post, via Reuters
item.media:description: Jason Rezaian, a reporter for The Washington Post in Tehran, and his wife have been detained by Iranian authorities since last month.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: 21 Guilty in Mine Shaft Murders Echoing Chinese Film
item.description: The killings followed the plot of the 2003 Chinese film “Blind Shaft,” in which con men kill workers and then claim to be family members to extort mine owners.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Coal miners in Shanxi Province taking a break. China's mines are notoriously dangerous; last year, more than a thousand people died in accidents in coal mines.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Israel’s Fair-Weather Fans
item.description: Liberal Zionists who criticize Israel think they’re indispensable, but Israel can and will survive without them.
item.dc:creator: By SHMUEL ROSNER

item.title: Prominent Rights Lawyer Is Freed From Chinese Prison, His Relatives Say
item.description: Before the police detained him in 2006, the lawyer Gao Zhisheng had emerged as one of China’s most combative human rights advocates.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Lighthouse Plan Likely to Raise Tensions in Disputed Sea
item.description: China, which has been criticized for projects in disputed waters, is reportedly planning to build lighthouses on five islands in the South China Sea.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Vietnamese authorities on May 7 shows a Chinese Coast Guard vessel using a water cannon against Vietnamese vessels near the Paracel Islands, after the Chinese deployment of an oil rig in the area.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Nigeria’s Power Problem
item.description: Time passed, the next monthly bill appeared, and hard on its heels came men with ladders to disconnect us.
item.dc:creator: By ADEWALE MAJA-PEARCE

item.title: Final Arguments in Pistorius Murder Trial Begin
item.description: Both sides in the trial of the athlete Oscar Pistorius are summarizing their cases before handing over the case to the presiding judge.
item.dc:creator: By NORIMITSU ONISHI and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius sat in the dock before closing arguments in his trial on Thursday in Pretoria, South Africa.

item.title: 2 Khmer Rouge Leaders Are Convicted in Cambodia
item.description: Two senior leaders of the Khmer Rouge, which brutalized Cambodia in the 1970s, were found guilty of crimes against humanity, in the first convictions of members of the regime’s leadership.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER and JULIA WALLACE
item.media:description: Soum Rithy, center, who lost his father and three siblings during the Khmer Rouge regime, hugged another survivor after the verdict was delivered.

item.title: In Greece, Migrants Are Desperate to Flee Again
item.description: They left countries like Iran and Afghanistan, ending up in poverty and as the targets of garbage thrown by angry citizens.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY
